Table.name: CONTEXT_HISTORY
Table.comment: Stores the chronological conversation history for all users. Each record corresponds to a single “turn” in a conversation, linked to the user and (optionally) the LLM used to generate the response. Stores the role (system, user, assistant, tool), the message content (JSON), and optional metadata (e.g., token counts, tool calls). A session_id groups multiple turns into a single conversation thread, and turn_index orders them within that thread. Key uses: Enables replay, audit, and context reconstruction for ongoing conversations.
Table.commentInRDBMS: Stores the chronological conversation history for all users.

Column.name: CTX_ID
Column.comment: ctx_id — Primary key for the conversation turn. Uniquely identifies a single row in orac.context_history. Automatically generated by Oracle on insert (generated always as identity). Used as the foreign key target for related records such as embeddings (orac.context_embeddings.ctx_id). This ID remains fixed for the lifetime of the row and is never reused.
Column.commentInRDBMS: ctx_id — Primary key for the conversation turn.

Column.name: USER_ID
Column.comment: user_id — Primary key for the orac.users table. A unique numeric identifier for each registered user. Generated automatically by Oracle on insert (generated always as identity). Used as the target of foreign key references from related tables such as orac.user_preferences.user_id and orac.context_history.user_id. This value is system-assigned, immutable, and never reused.
Column.commentInRDBMS: user_id — Primary key for the orac.users table.

Column.name: LLM_ID
Column.comment: llm_id — Primary key for the orac.llm_registry table. Uniquely identifies a registered large language model configuration. Generated automatically by Oracle on insert (generated always as identity). Used as a foreign key in related tables such as orac.context_history.llm_id to associate conversation turns with the specific LLM used. Immutable once created and never reused.
Column.commentInRDBMS: llm_id — Primary key for the orac.llm_registry table.

Column.name: SESSION_ID
Column.comment: session_id — Conversation session key for orac.context_history. Groups multiple conversation turns into a single logical dialogue thread. Supplied by the application, typically as a UUID or other unique string when the conversation starts. Used in combination with turn_index to enforce a unique ordering of turns within the session. This value is consistent across all turns in the same conversation and is never reassigned to unrelated threads.
Column.commentInRDBMS: session_id — Conversation session key for orac.context_history.

Column.name: TURN_INDEX
Column.comment: turn\_index — Ordinal position of a turn within a conversation (orac.context\_history). Identifies the 1-based order of a message within a session\_id thread. Not auto-generated; supplied by the application at insert time. Combined with session\_id it is unique (constraint uq\_ctx\_hist\_session\_turn) and defines the session’s ordering. Used to fetch the nth turn in a session and to reconstruct conversation state deterministically. Normally not changed after insert; altering it can violate uniqueness or disrupt chronological order. Optionally enforce positivity with check (turn\_index >= 1). Indexed via the unique constraint on (session\_id, turn\_index) for fast ordered reads within a session.
Column.commentInRDBMS: turn\_index — Ordinal position of a turn within a conversation (orac.context\_history).

Column.name: ROLE
Column.comment: role — Actor/type of the conversation turn (orac.context_history). Allowed values: 'system', 'user', 'assistant', 'tool' (enforced by a check constraint). Semantics: 'system' = system/directives; 'user' = human input; 'assistant' = model output; 'tool' = tool/function call result or external service output. Source: set by the application at insert time; typically not changed afterward. Usage: filter and report by actor, separate human vs model vs tool content, reconstruct dialogue flow, and control which turns are included in prompts/RAG. Notes: treat as an enum; keep values stable. If new roles are introduced, update both the check constraint and the application’s role mapping.
Column.commentInRDBMS: role — Actor/type of the conversation turn (orac.context_history).

Column.name: CONTENT
Column.comment: content — JSON payload of the conversation turn (orac.context_history). Semantics: stores the lossless message content for this turn; typically includes text and may include structured parts such as tool/function call inputs/outputs, citations, and attachment metadata. Do not store embeddings here (see orac.context_embeddings.lossless_text and embedding). Source: supplied by the application at insert time; treat as an immutable audit record of what was sent/received. Validation: native json type guarantees well-formed JSON; any schema/shape validation is enforced by the application. Size: can hold large payloads; for very large or multi-part messages, consider splitting into multiple embeddings while keeping a single content record. Indexing: add JSON path or function-based indexes for frequent queries (e.g., json_value(content,'$.text')), routine reads rely on the (session_id, turn_index) index. Security: avoid storing secrets or tokens in content; redact sensitive fields before insert if tool outputs include credentials.
Column.commentInRDBMS: content — JSON payload of the conversation turn (orac.context_history).

Column.name: TOKENS_USED
Column.comment: tokens_used — Total model tokens consumed for this turn (orac.context_history). Type: number, nullable. Meaning: aggregate token count reported by the provider for the operation that produced this turn, typically prompt + completion. For “user” turns with no model call, leave null (or store an app-computed estimate only if you standardize it). Source: set by the application from provider usage metadata; if multiple model/tool calls occur within one turn, store the summed total here and keep the per-call breakdown in meta (e.g., {"tokens":{"prompt":..,"completion":..,"calls":[...]}}). Usage: cost accounting, rate-limit monitoring, context-window budgeting, and analytics. Notes: tokenization is model-specific; avoid cross-model comparisons without normalization. If unknown, prefer null over guesses. For embedding operations, record counts in orac.context_embeddings.tokens_used.
Column.commentInRDBMS: tokens_used — Total model tokens consumed for this turn (orac.context_history).

Column.name: META
Column.comment:
meta — Free-form metadata for the turn (orac.context\_history).
Meaning: auxiliary facts about how this turn was produced and used (telemetry, provider details, per-call stats). Not the user/assistant text itself and not embeddings. Source: populated by the application from LLM/tool responses and runtime telemetry at insert time (and optionally on updates).
Typical contents: provider/model name and version; request/response ids; temperature/top\_p/seed/stop\_reason; latency and timestamps; retry counts and error info; moderation/safety results; token breakdowns (e.g., {tokens:{prompt, completion, total, calls:\[…]}}); tool/function call arguments and results; RAG citations (document ids, chunk offsets, scores); attachment/file metadata; prompt/template identifiers; any feature flags used.
Usage: analytics and debugging; cost and latency tracking; reproducibility of a turn; filtering (e.g., only turns with tool calls); audit trails for safety and compliance.
Constraints and conventions: treat as application-defined schema; keep stable keys; include a small “schema\_version” field for forward compatibility; avoid secrets/PII or redact before insert; do not store vector data here (use orac.context\_embeddings). For user turns with no model/tool activity, meta may be null or contain only client-side context.
Indexing: add JSON path or function-based indexes for hot fields you query often (for example, json\_value(meta,'\$.tokens.total'), json\_exists(meta,'\$.toolCalls')).
Column.commentInRDBMS: meta — Free-form metadata for the turn (orac.context\_history).
